title: 'Involved grandparenting and child well-being'
abstractText: This, the first national study of young people's views, surveyed 1596 children (aged 11-16) in schools across England and Wales  showed that grandparents were heavily involved in young people's lives  undertaking many tasks traditionally associated with parenting;  this involvement  was significantly associated with higher levels of well-being amongst the grandchildren, particularly at times of parental separation and divorce.  In times of family adversity grandparent involvement 'buffered' the impact of the adversity on the children.
